abstract_summ: CONCLUSIONS: In preterm infants with RDS receiving CPAP and ≤30% FiO(2), infants with higher oxygen saturations had greater success in transitioning off CPAP.BACKGROUND: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is associated with marginal decrease in chronic lung disease (CLD).DESIGN: In this retrospective pre–post analysis, outcomes were compared in two preterm infant groups (≤32 weeks gestation).We tested the hypothesis that preterm infants that successfully transition off CPAP have higher oxygen saturations prior to weaning compared with infants who fail weaning from CPAP.This trial aims to evaluate the effects of two methods of surfactant administration, LISA or endotracheal surfactant administration followed by low peak pressure (LPPSA) ventilation, in preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).We recommend caution when initiating oral feedings in preterm infants on NCPAP without evaluating the safety of the infants and their readiness for oral feedings.
title_summ: Feasibility of combining two individualized lung recruitment maneuvers at birth for very low gestational age infants: a retrospective cohort studyDecreasing Chronic Lung Disease Associated with Bubble CPAP Technology: Experience at Five YearsOxygen saturation histograms predict nasal continuous positive airway pressure-weaning success in preterm infantsAn experience with a bubble CPAP bundle: is chronic lung disease preventable?The effects of oral feeding while on nasal continuous positive airway pressure (NCPAP) in preterm infantsLess invasive surfactant administration versus endotracheal surfactant instillation followed by limited peak pressure ventilation in preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome in China: study protocol for a randomized controlled trialMinimally invasive surfactant therapy versus InSurE in preterm neonates of 28 to 34 weeks with respiratory distress syndrome on non-invasive positive pressure ventilation—a randomized controlled trial
title_abstract_phrases: Less invasive surfactant administration versus endotracheal surfactant instillation followed by limited peak pressure ventilation in preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome in China: study protocol for a randomized controlled trialBACKGROUND: Less invasive surfactant administration (LISA) is a way of giving surfactant without endotracheal intubation and has shown to be promising in reducing the incidence of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) in preterm infants.Oxygen saturation histograms predict nasal continuous positive airway pressure-weaning success in preterm infantsBACKGROUND: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is widely used in preterm infants.CONCLUSIONS: In preterm infants with RDS receiving CPAP and ≤30% FiO(2), infants with higher oxygen saturations had greater success in transitioning off CPAP.An experience with a bubble CPAP bundle: is chronic lung disease preventable?BACKGROUND: Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is associated with marginal decrease in chronic lung disease (CLD).This trial aims to evaluate the effects of two methods of surfactant administration, LISA or endotracheal surfactant administration followed by low peak pressure (LPPSA) ventilation, in preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).The effects of oral feeding while on nasal continuous positive airway pressure (NCPAP) in preterm infantsOBJECTIVE: To determine whether delaying oral feeding until coming off NCPAP will alter feeding and respiratory-related morbidities in preterm infants.
